docs.title: ANTs
docs.description: Advanced Normalization Tools (ANTs) computes high-dimensional mappings to capture the statistics of brain structure and function. It is a state-of-the-art medical image registration and segmentation toolkit that allows one to organize, visualize, and statistically explore large biomedical image sets. ANTs integrates imaging modalities in space and time and works across species or organ systems with minimal customization. It has won several international, unbiased competitions such as MICCAI, BRATS, and STACOM.
affiliation: Penn Image Computing and Science Lab (PICSL), University of Pennsylvania
literature: Avants, B. B., Epstein, C. L., Grossman, M., & Gee, J. C. (2008). Symmetric diffeomorphic image registration with cross-correlation: Evaluating automated labeling of elderly and neurodegenerative brain. Medical Image Analysis, 12(1), 26-41. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.media.2007.06.004

Avants, B. B., Tustison, N. J., Song, G., Cook, P. A., Klein, A., & Gee, J. C. (2011). A reproducible evaluation of ANTs similarity metric performance in brain image registration. NeuroImage, 54(3), 2033-2044. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2010.09.025

Tustison, N. J., Cook, P. A., Holbrook, A. J., Johnson, H. J., Muschelli, J., Devenyi, G. A., ... & Avants, B. B. (2021). The ANTsX ecosystem for quantitative biological and medical imaging. Scientific Reports, 11, 9068. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-021-87564-6
